issue.body:
`-sequenceMany:` is meant to make clear the difference between piping data through subscribables with `-selectMany:` vs. chaining a subscribable after another. It's the difference between `>>=` and `>>`.

I'm not crazy on the name, but it was my favorite of the ones I came up with.
issue.title: Added -sequenceMany:

comment.body: It is analogous to `>>=` and `>>`, but it's not entirely clear to me how this would be used. Could you add a unit test that demonstrates some idiomatic usage?

issue.body: tweaked ajax.js to not silently fail
issue.title: ajax: better error handling

comment.body: hm, well I guess this pr fails, but the issue remains - zepto shouldn't silently fail. one ajax test fails because of this (see: #388).

pull_request.body:
`-sequenceMany:` is meant to make clear the difference between piping data through subscribables with `-selectMany:` vs. sequencing a subscribable after another. It's the difference between `>>=` and `>>`.

I'm not crazy on the name, but it was my favorite of the ones I came up with.

issue.body:
Hi,

i changed the project to enable building IPA for ad-hoc distribution.
I simply set the skip install to YES, and moved the headers from public to project

now you can build an IPA when choosing "build for archive" in the xcode menu
issue.title: the librairy was blocking the build archive in xcode

comment.body:
I am going to have to look into this.  I think I may have overlooked this bug for two reasons.

* Never archived PDTwitterTest
* Square's codebase has build step that removes the headers when we archive.

The reason we mark these as Public is to make it so header inclusion is really easy (all the external libraries's headers are copied into the build products directory and you don't need to explicitly include every dependency).

issue.body: The css if test for removing a style is `value ==''` which of course will test positive for 0 values. This has implications for other kinds of styles. For example, if the border-width is set in an element to a non-zero value in the css file and we need to use the css function to add a 0 width on the element in some circumstance, this passes through.
issue.title: Setting css opacity to 0 will result in opacity style being removed

comment.body: Awesome. Glad to have contributed to a great project

milestone.description: Release candidate 2, mostly for known minor bugs that we should fix before 1.0
milestone.title: v1.0rc2

issue.body: I'm not sure if this is something that you want to include in zepto or not as it does add a little bit more code, but I've added the ability to do deep object copying as I've been using that a lot for configuration options in some of my projects.
issue.title: Deep object copying

comment.body:
No tools, just brain. The code in this pull request calls `$.extend` recursively which is very wasteful because of additional logic with argument handling and array.slice call. My version has a more lightweight function to call recursively while $.extend is just a single wrapper around all that.

Otherwise I use runtime profiling in webkit dev tools

issue.body:
```
Pod::Spec.new do |s|
  s.name     = 'SVProgressHUD'
  s.version  = '0.7'
  s.platform = :ios
  s.license  = 'MIT'
  s.summary  = 'A clean and lightweight progress HUD for your iOS app.'
  s.homepage = 'http://samvermette.com/199'
  s.author   = { 'Sam Vermette' => 'hello@samvermette.com' }
  s.source   = { :git => 'https://github.com/samvermette/SVProgressHUD.git', :tag => '0.7' }

  s.description = 'SVProgressHUD is an easy-to-use, clean and lightweight progress HUD for iOS. ' \
                  'It\'s a simplified and prettified alternative to the popular MBProgressHUD. '  \
                  'Its fade in/out animations are highly inspired on Lauren Britcher\'s HUD in '  \
                  'Tweetie for iOS. The success and error icons are from Glyphish.'

  s.source_files = 'SVProgressHUD/*.{h,m}'

  s.framework    = 'QuartzCore'
  s.resources    = 'SVProgressHUD/SVProgressHUD.bundle'
  s.requires_arc = true
end
```
issue.title: SVProgressHUD 0.7 needs s.requires_arc = true

comment.body: Ah, sorry, I didn't realize how old the tagged version was. I'll ask him to make a new version.
